general.name: Project Name
general.description: The name of the project. This is used in telemetry and other places to identify your flight.

general.name: Main Board Type
general.description: The type of computer that the flight software is running on. This is important for the interfacing with the hardware.

general.name: Starting Procedure
general.description: The flight procedure that the flight software should start with. See the flight procedures section.

extension.name: Extension ID
extension.description: The numerical ID of the extension. This is used internally. They must start at 1, be sequential, and be unique.

extension.name: Extension Name
extension.description: The name of the extension. Used for identifying data, errors, and other items. It's best to keep this short but identifiable. Must be unique.

extension.name: Extension Type
extension.description: The type of extension. This refers to the actual hardware that the software is interfacing with.

extension.name: Extension Interface
extension.description: The interface that the extension is using to communicate with the main board.

extension.name: Extension Category
extension.description: The category of the extension. This is used internally for data processing and telemetry. It's important to choose the relevant category.

extension.name: Extension Update Interval
extension.description: The interval at which the extension should update in milliseconds. A higher value will result in less frequent data updates.

extension.name: Flight Critical
extension.description: Whether or not the extension is flight critical. This is used to determine how the flight software should handle errors. Extensions that are important, such as a gps, should be labeled as flight critical, otherwise they may be shut down after repeated critical errors.

debugging.name: Print All Errors to Console
debugging.description: Whether or not to print errors to the console instead of capturing them in the error stream. This is useful for debugging.

debugging.name: Enable Console Interface
debugging.description: Whether or not to enable the console interface. Helpful for debugging without the web interface.

debugging.name: Console Update Interval
debugging.description: How often the console interface should update in milliseconds. A higher value will result in less frequent updates.

debugging.name: GFS Web Socket
debugging.description: Whether or not to enabled the web socket. This is used for the web interface. If disabled, the web interface will not work.

debugging.name: Web Socket Port
debugging.description: The port that the web socket will use. Used for connecting to the web interface. This should be left unchanged unless you have a reason for it.

general.name: Enable Telemetry
general.description: Whether or not to enabled telemetry. This is required for APRS, SSTV, and Data Packets. In the current implementation, this requires an amateur radio license.

general.name: Callsign
general.description: A FCC (or equivalent) registered callsign. This is required for telemetry.

aprs.name: APRS Enabled
aprs.description: Whether or not to enable APRS. Requires a callsign and a valid telemetry configuration. The rate at which packets are sent is determined by the flight procedure defined by the user.

aprs.name: APRS Frequency
aprs.description: The frequency that APRS packets will be transmitted on. See aprs.fi for more information.

aprs.name: Source SSID
aprs.description: The SSID that will be used to identify your callsign. See the APRS specification for more information.

aprs.name: APRS Destination Address
aprs.description: This is the destination address that will be used in all packets. See the APRS specification for more information.

aprs.name: APRS Destination SSID
aprs.description: This is the SSID that will be used to identify the destination callsign. See the APRS specification for more information.

aprs.name: APRS Symbol Table
aprs.description: The symbol table that will be used. `/` is the primary table and `\` is the alternate table. See the APRS specification for more information.

aprs.name: APRS Symbol
aprs.description: The symbol that will be used to identify your position. This is a single character. The default is '/' which is a dot on both tables. See the APRS specification for more information.

aprs.name: APRS Telemetry Enabled
aprs.description: If enabled, critical data will be sent as APRS telemetry packets. This will be configurable in the future.

aprs.name: APRS Telemetry Destination
aprs.description: This is the destination address that will be used in all telemetry packets. See the APRS specification for more information.

aprs.name: APRS Position Enabled
aprs.description: If enabled, compressed position reports will be sent. This is required for APRS tracking.

aprs.name: APRS Comment
aprs.description: This is the comment that will be sent with each APRS position report. See the APRS specification for more information.

sstv.name: SSTV Enabled
sstv.description: Indicates whether or not SSTV is enabled. This requires a valid telemetry configuration, a callsign, and a camera extension. The rate at which images are sent is determined by the flight procedure defined by the user.

sstv.name: SSTV Frequency
sstv.description: The frequency that will be used to transmit SSTV images. See your relevant Band Plan for more information.

sstv.name: SSTV Mode
sstv.description: The SSTV mode that will be used. Currently, only Robot 36 is supported.

sstv.name: SSTV Data Overlay
sstv.description: If enabled, data defined internally as 'critical' will be overlaid on the image.

data-packets.name: Data Packets Enabled
data-packets.description: If enabled, PSK data packets can be sent. These can be decoded with FLDIGI The contents of these packets are defined by the user. The rate at which packets are sent is determined by the flight procedure defined by the user.

data-packets.name: Data Packets Frequency
data-packets.description: The frequency that will be used to transmit data packets. See your relevant Band Plan for more information.

data-packets.name: Data Packets Mode
data-packets.description: The PSK31 mode that will be used. All modes supported by FLDIGI are supported for both BPSK and QPSK.

data-packets.name: Morse Callsign
data-packets.description: If enabled, the callsign will be sent in 20wpm morse code at the end of each packet. This may be a legal requirement, for station identification, in some places so please check your local regulations.

data-packets.name: Data Packets Comment
data-packets.description: This is a comment that will be sent with each data packet. This is not required but may be added. There is a maximum length of 200 characters.

radios.name: Radio ID
radios.description: The ID of the radio. This is used for internal identification. Must be sequential, starting at 1.

radios.name: Radio Name
radios.description: The name of the radio. This is used for data and error logging. Must be unique. It's recommended to use a meaningful name.

radios.name: Radio Type
radios.description: The type of radio. This is used to determine how the radio is interface with. Currently, only DRA/SA modules are supported with plans to support other types in the future.

radios.name: Radio Priority
radios.description: The priority of the radio. If multiple radios are available for a given mode/frequency, the one with the lowest priority value will be used. If multiple radios have the same priority, the one with the lower ID will be used. If there is only one radio, this is irrelevant.

radios.name: PTT Delay
radios.description: The delay in milliseconds between the 'PTT On' command and the start of audio transmission. This can be used to fix pesky issues with some radios.

radios.name: Frequency Ranges
radios.description: This is a list of frequency ranges that a radio can operate in. Each range is defined by a lower and upper frequency. Radios can only be used for a given mode/frequency if the configured frequency is within one of the ranges defined here. You do not need to define the range as what the radio is capable of, but rather what you want to use. At least one range must be provided.

radios.name: Modes
radios.description: This is a list of modes that a radio can operate in. This is helpful if you have multiple radios and want to use one for a specific purpose.

radios.name: Features
radios.description: This is a list of features that a radio supports. This is helpful as there are different types of radios that the software currently supports. Some of these radios have features that other do not.

radio-interface.name: Interface Type
radio-interface.description: The type of interface that the radio uses. Currently, only UART is supported for DRA/SA modules.

radio-interface.name: UART Path
radio-interface.description: The path to the UART device. This is usually something like `/dev/ttyAMA0` or `/dev/ttyS0`.

radio-interface.name: UART Baud Rate
radio-interface.description: The baud rate of the UART radio interface. This is usually something like `9600` or `115200`.

radio-gpio.name: PTT GPIO
radio-gpio.description: The BCM pin number of the GPIO that is used for PTT. This is required for some radios. Pick this pin carefully as many pins have weird behavior at boot time and when not controlled by the software. This pin will be driven high when the radio is transmitting and low when it is not.

radio-gpio.name: Power GPIO
radio-gpio.description: The BCM pin number of the GPIO pin that is used to control the power to the radio. This can be useful for power saving. This pin will be driven high when the radio is powered on and low when it is not.

radio-gpio.name: Squelch Detect GPIO
radio-gpio.description: The BCM pin number of the GPIO pin that is used to detect when the radio is receiving a signal. This is an input pin. This can be helpful as the radio need not be in monitor mode to receive transmissions. This pin should be driven high when the radio has is receiving a signal and low when it is not.

data-log-contents.name: Data Source
data-log-contents.description: The source of the data. This could be an extension, a module, or something else. It's best to look at the data stream to see what you can/want to use.

data-log-contents.name: Data Unit
data-log-contents.description: The unit of the data. Sources often provide more than one type of data, so this is used to differentiate between them. If you use '*', all units from the source will be logged. If you're not sure, look at the data stream.

data-packet-contents.name: Data Source
data-packet-contents.description: The source of the data. This could be an extension, a module, or something else. It's best to look at the data stream to see what you can/want to use. This is identical to the data log configuration.

data-packet-contents.name: Data Unit
data-packet-contents.description: The unit of data from the source. This is identical to the data log configuration, so refer to that. Be mindful that the more you select, the more data you will send, and the more time you will need to transmit. This is especially of concern when using slower baud rates.

data-packet-contents.name: Data Alias
data-packet-contents.description: This is the alias that you want to assign to this source/unit combination. This is helpful to reduce the amount of data that is being send in data packets. For example, if you use the system data extension, you give it a maximum length name of 15 characters like 'sys_information', and then you add 'ram_used_prcnt' as your unit, it would be labeled in the data packet as 'sys_information:ram_used_prcnt'. With an alias, you could shorten this to something that is still meaningful like 'ram_usd'.

data-packet-contents.name: Data Rounding
data-packet-contents.description: If this data source/unit produces floating point data, you can use this optional configuration option to round it to a certain number of decimal places. This is another useful tool to reduce packet size.

flight-procedure-general.name: Flight Procedure Type
flight-procedure-general.description: This is the 'type' of procedure. This is more than just semantics. The flight computer will use this to determine what to do and when, at different stages of the flight.

flight-procedure-general.name: Flight Procedure Enabled
flight-procedure-general.description: If a flight procedure is enabled, it may be switched to by the flight computer. If a procedure is disabled, the computer will ignore it.

intervals.name: Data Log Interval
intervals.description: This is the interval, in seconds, that the data log will be written to the data log file. Set to '0' to disabled. This will write all items specified in the data log configuration, regardless of whether or not they have changed.

intervals.name: Data Packet Interval
intervals.description: The interval, in seconds, that a data packet will be generated and added to the TX queue. Set to '0' to disable. Keep in mind that if you are generating large packets with low baud rates, you can generate packets faster than you can transmit them. If the queue becomes full, packets will be dropped.

intervals.name: SSTV Interval
intervals.description: The interval, in seconds, that an SSTV image will be generated and added to the TX queue. Set to '0' to disable. Robot36 takes 36 seconds to transmit, so be careful with this setting.

intervals.name: APRS Position Interval
intervals.description: The interval, in seconds, that an APRS position packet will be generated and added to the TX queue. Set to '0' to disable for this procedure.

intervals.name: APRS Telemetry Interval
intervals.description: The interval, in seconds, that an APRS telemetry packet will be generated and added to the TX queue. Set to '0' to disable for this procedure.

intervals.name: Health Check Interval
intervals.description: The interval, in seconds, that a health check will be performed. This is used to determine if the flight computer is still functioning properly or if it should switch flight procedures.
